items.synopsis: The RBA has surprised markets and economists by lifting interest rates to 3.85 per cent, after being widely predicted to stay on hold for a second month. Follow the day's events with our live blog.

title.children: Reserve Bank hikes cash rate to 3.85 per cent as Qantas announces Alan Joyce's successor

schema.headline: Live updates: Reserve Bank hikes cash rate to 3.85 per cent, ASX opens lower, Qantas appoints new CEO to replace Alan Joyce

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX plummets to three-week low after RBA hikes rates
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Australian share market has plummeted to finish at its lowest level in more than three weeks, after the RBA announced a surprise 11th rate hike in the past 12 months. The ASX200 finished down 67.2 points, or 0.92% at 7,267. All sectors finished in the red, with the real estate sector shedding the most, down -2.1%. The biggest gains of the day went to: Pinnacle Investment +6.1% Cleanaway Waste Management +5.8% Lake Resources +5.65 Telix Pharmaceuticals +3.1% Graincorp +2.2% The bottom five worst performers for the day were: Computershare -4.8% Mirvac -4.2% Imugene -3.9% De Grey Mining -3.75 Bellevue Gold -3.6%

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Watch: Treasurer says rate hike proof inflation is main economic challenge
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has just responded to the RBA's decision to lift interest rates, and foreshadowed some measures to ease the cost of living in next week's federal budget.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Thank you!
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Okay everyone, I'm sorry but I have to go now. Thanks for sending me your questions. I'm really sorry I couldn't get to all of them. There were a lot today. And best of luck, Natty.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Declining rates for savers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Gareth, we are retirees and for some years our savings behave been earning tiny amounts of interest.  So I suppose one might say that it will be our turn for a little while.  If one looks at Australia’s interest rates over the last 40 years, interest rates have rarely been below 5% pa. - Miles. I have complete sympathy for you Miles. In the inflation-targeting era (since the early 1990s), interest rates have been in long-term decline - except for now. It's been increasingly great for asset owners. But people who rely on interest rates from their savings to supplement their income have not benefited.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Governments are happy for the focus to be on the RBA
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody:
Governments are getting off far too lightly re their contribution to this problem.  Even now various Budgets are promising relief for low/middle income and mortgaged households - fair enough.  But if this in not immediately countered by a tax hit to middle/high and home owning households the net impact on the economy (i.e. demand) is clearly going to be positive.  Completely at odds with what the RBA is trying to acheive...
 - Mike. There's a good point in here. Governments have got off too lightly for contributing to this inflation. The RBA has become a scapegoat of sorts. Your point about the budget is also interesting. There are credible forecasts at the moment that the Albanese Government could actually deliver an exceptionally-thin budget surplus next week. That's for a few reasons, but especially because commodity prices have been far higher than Treasury was forecasting, and because the exceptionally-high levels of immigration we're seeing out the moment are much higher than were forecast. And budget surpluses help to suck inflation out of the system. So on the surface, the budget settings look like they may be supporting the RBA's attempt to dampen inflation. But that's only on the surface. The budget will probably show that there will be a heap of structural problems down the line that will be hard to address.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Is it a cop-out?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Given that this period of rapid inflation is reported to have been affected by high corporate profits rather than wages, why is the RBA so focused on slowing/preventing wage growth? To someone who doesn't know a lot about economics, it almost feels like they're taking the easy way out trying to keep the big companies happy. - Bec. The RBA can't do much about supply. It can only influence demand (in the short and medium term) by moving interest rates up and down. That's why the RBA is always keeping an eye on wages because wages feed into demand-driven inflation. This is just the system past policymakers built. In the inflation-targeting era, it's been the RBA's job to manage inflation - and the economic cycle - by moving interest rates around to influence demand .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: A legitimate question
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Just a bit puzzled as to who these "savers" are that today's rise is meant to be good news for... - Craig. Many people would love to have some savings set aside that could generate interest.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Inflation and recessions
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hi just wondering if there is any historical data that's shows how high previous inflation rates were when they actually triggered a recession or a recessionary curve. As a baby boomer who lived through interest rates of 12% and higher 30 years ago, current inflation seems not high at all - Bill. A significant difference with today's environment, compared to past eras, is the level of debt in the economy. When my folks bought their first home in the early 1970s it cost them $35,000. That was 3x their annual income. Today, properties are typically worth upwards of 7x annual income, and well above 10x to 12x in some of our capital cities. And because the cash rate was 0.1% for a time, the size of the recent mortgages banks were willing to extend to people were huge. So, relatively small increases in interest rates are much more impactful today. Now, this might be a slightly left-field way of answering your question quickly, but I recently made a graph of the time when Australia's economic authorities experimented with targeting the money supply to control inflation (at the peak of Milton Friedman's monetarism craze in the late 1970s and early 1980s). It was when Malcolm Fraser was prime minister and John Howard was Treasurer (for most of the time). There were three recessions in that period, including the recession in the early 1980s which was especially bad. It shows how high inflation was in that era. Note inflation fell after each recession. Although, inflation shot up again in 1985, after the Hawke Government floated the dollar in 1983 and deregulated the financial sector.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Good news for savers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: How about reporting on the Australians for whom today’s decision is good news - the savers? - David Howey. Depending on how much of the rate increase will be passed onto savers (if at all), it is good news for savers.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Puzzled. Befuddled. Bemused.
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Alan Oster, NAB's chief economist, says he's finding it difficult to understand the RBA board's behaviour lately. He spoke to my colleague David Chau earlier, and he had this to say about today's rate hike and the accompanying statement from governor Phil Lowe. Q: "Recent property market data for Canberra showed house prices are on their way up again. Is the wealth effect something the RBA may be concerned about? Especially if house prices continue their recovery? People might feel they are better off economically and might spend more, which might make it harder for the Reserve Bank to bring inflation down? Alan Oster: "That is possible. But let's face it. It is mainly a Sydney thing. Up over 1% in Sydney and across Australia, 0.5%. "Yes, there is a wealth effect associated, but also a very direct interest-rate effect. It is much bigger than the wealth effect. The nice news is these are probably bottoming out. But the fact that the economy is still going to slow I think is an issue. "Once again the Reserve Bank made it very difficult for us all to understand what the hell they are talking about, to be brutally honest," he said.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Help the ABC investigate mortgage lending
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Our investigations team would like your help. Today’s hike will increase the pressure on borrowers who took out large loans while rates were at historic lows. ABC Investigations has launched a crowdsourced investigation into mortgage lending in Australia. They’re investigating how we got into this situation, who is to blame and what needs to change – and they need your help. If you have a mortgage, or if you work in lending, regulation or financial support services, they want to hear from you. Go to abc.net.au/lending to share your story.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Rate hike 'likely to be the last', CoreLogic says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: CoreLogic's research director, Tim Lawless thinks today's rate hike will be the last of this cycle. He says today's interest rate decision was always going to be a "line ball", but "the 25 basis point lift is likely to be the last in what has been the most rapid rate hiking cycle on record". "Although inflation has been trending lower since peaking in the December quarter 2022, today’s rate hike reflects the RBA’s uncertainty about how ‘sticky’ inflation might be amid persistently tight labour markets and new evidence that housing prices have moved through their low point," Mr Lawless said. "Although the RBA didn’t touch on the recent more positive housing trend, the statement following the meeting highlighted the rapid drop in housing prices since rate hikes commenced could be a factor in slowing household spending (alongside high interest rates and high cost of living pressures). "Time will tell whether the latest rate hike is enough to send the recent positive trend in home values into reverse, however our anticipation is the market will continue to level out on the expectation that interest rates have peaked and the imbalance between housing demand and supply will persist for some time yet."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Rates rises until...
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Given the RBA’s comment that they expect inflation to reduce to 3% by mid-2025 (upper bound of the target range) are we likely to see ongoing rate hikes until then? - Vickie. Economists say it would be reasonable to expect rates to rise a little more this year, but I haven't seen anyone suggest that rates will keep rising until mid-2025. There are still hundreds of thousands of households with fixed-rate mortgages that have yet to roll onto variable loans. When they do, they'll be getting a big interest rate shock. The RBA's aware of that. It knows there's a lag between rate hikes and their impact on economic activity, and it's expecting inflation to slowly fall over the next 24 months as the rate rises that have already occurred work their way through the system.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Why aren't banks passing on higher interest rates to savers?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody:
As a retired person with extremely limited funds, I want the banks to be forced to pass on more of the interest rate rises to people like me. 
They seem to unfairly hit both savers and borrowers, and just make more profit. - Ros. Hi Ros, we published an article on this issue last month from Peter Martin from the Conversation. I've posted the link below. But here's an excerpt from the piece with a very good graph that could explain your situation:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The RBA's focus on demand and wages
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Am I understanding this correctly? Is the policy really to keep wage growth down? - Sean. Central banks say they can only control demand. They have no control over supply. So when they move interest rates up and down, they're trying to manipulate demand. Wages are one of the key drivers of demand, and employment (and unemployment) drives wages. The RBA knows this inflationary episode didn't start with exceptionally-strong wages growth. But it's very concerned that workers will demand (and start winning) wage growth to match this high inflation because that could spark a "wage-price spiral," which would, in turn, make it even harder for the RBA to get this inflation back down and under control. So, the RBA doesn't want wages to grow too quickly. It wants them to stay relatively subdued and for these high prices to eventually wash out of the system, so everything can go back to normal.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: More rate hikes, and a recipe for an economic slowdown
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here are some comments from Callam Pickering, an economist at global job site Indeed. Mr Pickering is a former RBA economist so he has insight into how RBA officials would be thinking about things. He's just put out this note on the rate decision, which I think is worth quoting in full: "The flow of recent economic data provides a compelling case for further rate hikes,” he said. "While it was also possible to mount a convincing argument for no change, the RBA clearly felt that economic conditions remained too strong to facilitate a sustainable return to its 2-3% inflation target within a reasonable time-frame. "The RBA anticipates that further rate hikes may well be needed to defeat the current inflation outbreak. However, given that rate hikes hit the Australian economy with a considerable lag, the RBA is also mindful that the economy hasn’t yet felt the full impact of the first rate hikes let alone the ones that followed. That points towards a pretty measured and cautious approach over the next three to six months. "The key challenge for the RBA is balancing the risks of high inflation against the likelihood that excess tightening plunges the economy into a recession or severe downturn which harms Australian workers and businesses unnecessarily. There is plenty of anecdotal evidence of households doing it rough but so far that hasn’t translated into any meaningful moderation in household or business spending. "While there were signs of inflation moderating in the monthly figures, sources of domestically-driven inflation remained too strong. Prices of non-tradable goods - a useful proxy for inflation driven by domestic factors - have increased at an annualised pace of 8.1% over the past six months. It won’t be possible for inflation to sustainably return to its 2-3% target unless that number gets down to the high 3% or low 4% range. "Unfortunately, achieving that requires you to squash domestic demand for goods and services. That normally means higher unemployment, reduced household spending and business investment." " That said, we anticipate that the Australian economy will slow considerably over the second half of the year. This is centered on the belief that household conditions will deteriorate due to the combination of much higher mortgage repayments, softish asset prices and the unprecedented decline in inflation-adjusted wages. This is a recipe for an economic slowdown if ever I’ve seen one. "While the May increase will come as an unwelcome surprise to many, we don’t anticipate that rates will continue to rise for long. "We are very close to rates reaching the cycle peak and that will likely become clear over the next three to six months.”

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Decision to lift interest rates a 'big surprise' for NAB's chief economist
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It was the less likely outcome, but the RBA choosing to lift the cash rate today has come as a surprise to many people — including NAB's chief economist Alan Oster. He was on ABC News Channel as the announcement was made, and he said the decision to hike rates was a "big surprise".

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Real wages are still declining
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I definitely am not getting more wages, I am getting more work but certainly not more money.  Everything has increased so my wage is going backwards. Yet no one is stepping in to rein in price gouging for the sake of gouging. Supermarket chains posting record profits, is this serious? Really disappointed.  - Jess. You're not alone Jess. We've had a few comments like this. People are hurting.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Rate retribution?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hi Gareth. After Jim Chalmers effectively threw Phil Lowe under the bus last month do you think this is retribution from the Governor of the RBA? Now we know that Phil adopts the 'its my way or the highway' approach to board meetings maybe he thought he'd give Chalmers something back? - Jeff. I don't think so. But we'll hear more from Phil Lowe tonight when he speaks in Perth, and in the Q & A afterwards. I'm sure he'll be asked why he (and his fellow board members) have opted to surprise people with this rate increase.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Watch: Treasurer Jim Chalmers responds to shock rate rise
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is about to speak after the RBA lifted the cash rate — you can tune in below:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The RBA doesn't want wages growing too quickly
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Dr Dwyfor Evans, the Head of APAC Macro Strategy at State Street Global Markets, says it's interesting what Phil Lowe has focused on in his statement following the monetary policy decision. "Inflation remains high relative to target, but the softer core inflation released last week gave the Bank some breathing space, particularly on concerns around mortgage rates, but the focus in this instance is high services prices and rising labour costs ," Mr Evans said. That's a reference to these lines in Dr Lowe's statement. " Services price inflation is still very high and broadly based and the experience overseas points to upside risks. " Unit labour costs are also rising briskly, with productivity growth remaining subdued. " Wages growth has picked up in response to the tight labour market and high inflation. At the aggregate level, wages growth is still consistent with the inflation target, provided that productivity growth picks up. The Board remains alert to the risk that expectations of ongoing high inflation contribute to larger increases in both prices and wages, especially given the limited spare capacity in the economy and the historically low rate of unemployment. Accordingly, it will continue to pay close attention to both the evolution of labour costs and the price-setting behaviour of firms. " So Dr Evans thinks that, even though core inflation has weakened enough recently to give the RBA some breathing space, the RBA is concerned enough about wages growth picking up that it wants to crimp some more demand. What's your experience with wages right now?

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How much extra could you be paying on your mortgage?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody:
Can you give us a link to the tool to show us how much our mortgage will go up as you have in previous months
 - Brett. I'm glad you asked, Brett — it's right here:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What do you want to know about today's interest rate decision?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Now's your time to ask — business reporter Gareth Hutchens is standing by to help us make sense of this unexpected decision by the Reserve Bank. What does it mean for mortgages, the economy, and next week's federal budget? Use the blue button at the top of blog and submit your question, and Gareth will get to them soon.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Inflation has 'passed its peak' but rate rise still needed, RBA says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's the question plenty of borrowers and economists have right now, and there are some clues in the statement issued by RBA governor Philip Lowe. Here's an excerpt from that statement: "Inflation in Australia has passed its peak, but at 7 per cent is still too high and it will be some time yet before it is back in the target range," the statement said. "Given the importance of returning inflation to target within a reasonable timeframe, the Board judged that a further increase in interest rates was warranted today. "The Board held interest rates steady last month to provide additional time to assess the state of the economy and the outlook. "While the recent data showed a welcome decline in inflation, the central forecast remains that it takes a couple of years before inflation returns to the top of the target range; inflation is expected to be 4.5% in 2023 and 3% in mid-2025."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: RBA lifts cash rate by 0.25 percentage points to 3.85%
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The RBA has increased the cash rate by 0.25 percentage points to 3.85%, after a one-off pause last month. It's the 11th increase in the space of a year. The move caught most traders by surprise, with the market only pricing in a 13 per cent chance of rates rising ahead of the RBA's 2:30pm AEST announcement. The majority of the major bank economists were also tipping the Reserve Bank to remain on hold this month, with two forecasting that it had reached the peak of its rate hike cycle at 3.6 per cent. The latest rate increase will add around $78 a month onto repayments for a half a million dollar home loan, if passed on in full by the banks. A customer owing $500,000 will now have seen their repayments rise by around $1,058 a month since the RBA started hiking rates in May last year.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Watch: The Reserve Bank's interest rate decision
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Want to watch it all unfold? You can tune in with the ABC's stream below:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What does the cash rate look like now?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Even with last month's pause, the cash rate is the highest its been in more than a decade. After rates were so low for so long, it makes the sudden rise of rates (which began 12 months ago) all the more dramatic — especially when you zoom out and look at the historical data back to the 1990s.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's what the big four banks think the RBA will do today
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Ahead of this afternoon's cash rate decision by the Reserve Bank board, Australia's big four banks have been predicting what the decision might be based on recent economic data. Three out of four think they will hold — while one bank thinks another 0.25 percentage point hike is on the way today. ANZ : hold at 3.6% Westpac : hold at 3.6% NAB : hold at 3.6% CBA : increase to 3.85% In fact, not only does Westpac think another pause is likely — they think interest rates have peaked at 3.6%. Markets are also expecting the RBA to leave rates on hold.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Coming up: The Reserve Bank's decision on interest rates
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Qantas news has really dominated much of the business news today, but there's still another major event coming up — interest rates. You're forgiven if it's slipped your mind, but in around an hour's time we'll hear what the RBA board has decided to do with the cash rate this month. It's widely tipped that rates will remain on hold at 3.6%, but at last month's meeting the board refused to rule out a future interest rate rise. We'll also get a bit more of an insight than normal into the bank's decision later on today too. Not only will the written decision for rates be published online at 2:30pm AEST, but governor Philip Lowe will be giving a speech at the RBA board dinner in Perth tonight. That's happening at 9:20pm AEST (which works out to be a more respectable 7:20pm in the west). The news just doesn't stop today — but stick with us and we'll bring you the latest as it unfolds.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's how the market is faring at 1:15pm AEST
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX 200 : -0.1% to 7,328 points All Ords: flat at 7,521 points Australian dollar : +0.1% at 66.34 US cents Dow Jones: -0.1% to 34,051 points S & P 500: -0.04% to 4,167 points Spot gold: flat at $US1,983.00/ounce Brent crude: +0.2% at $US79.44/barrel Iron ore: -0.1% to $US101.90 a tonne Bitcoin: +1.1% at $US27,958

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Qantas customers remain divided on the airline's service
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Vanessa Hudson has committed to improving the customer experience during her time as Qantas's chief executive, and judging by customers who reporter Harriet Tatham has spoken to today, they remain divided on the service provided by the national carrier. She spoke to passengers at Sydney's domestic Qantas terminal earlier today, who have mixed views on how the airline treats its customers. "I don't think they've don't everything perfect in the last couple of years but it's a tough gig," said Tracey Cooper, who arrived from Brisbane on a Qantas flight. Ron, who didn't provide his surname and flew in from Melbourne, says he thinks a number of Qantas customers are disappointed by the service. "Qantas was always a brand you loved and respected," he said. "I think COVID was rough on a lot of airlines and financially airlines took a hit and I think the way that Qantas responded to that has meant that their level of services dropped. "Customers who were very loyal to Qantas are questioning whether that loyalty was misplaced. "So I think they've got a way to go to win back their customers … and it's a good time for new management to come in and shake things up." But fellow passenger Nuzhat Abonty, who also arrived on the Melbourne flight, spoke very highly of the brand. "The service is amazing — especially the staff, the comfortable seats."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX in the red at lunch, Qantas shares shed 2.5pc
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: With that whirlwind Qantas news taking up most of the morning, let's check in with how the share market is faring. So far it's been a day of red, with all sectors (except education services) falling lower. Consumer non-cyclicals are down -0.6%, while the energy sector has shed -0.5%. The top five movers so far today are: Pinnacle Investment Management +5.3% Cleanaway Waste Management +4.8% Lake Resources +4.5% Telix Pharmaceuticals +3.4% Life360 +3% It's a mixed bag at the other end of the scale: Computershare -6.4% Imugene -3.9% Endeavour Group -2.6% Qantas Airways -2.5% Whitehaven Coal -2.4%

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Qantas lost $3 billion more than it made under Alan Joyce
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hi there, Sue Lannin jumping in for a guest post. I've been crunching Qantas' bottom line, and it has made huge losses during the 15 years of outgoing chief executive Alan Joyce's tenure. Aviation is a tough industry, with wars, pandemics, natural disasters, economic slowdowns, and financial crises the main factors that drive away passengers. Over the past 15 years, Qantas has been hit by COVID-19, which shut down the global travel industry, high fuel costs, fleet writedowns, and the global financial crisis, when toxic investments in the US almost brought down the world's financial system. So let's have a look at the financials while Mr Joyce was at the helm. Qantas net profit verses losses breakdown From 2008 to 2022, Qantas lost $2.9 billion, which wiped out the profits it made during the period. The rebound from COVID-19 has seen the airline return to profit for 2023, making a record $1 billion for the half year. Annual net losses 2022: $860 million loss 2021: $1.7 billion loss 2020: $1.9 billion loss 2014: $2.83 billion loss 2012: $$245 million loss 2008 - 2022 Total annual net loss: $7.6 billion Annual net profits 2019: $891 million profit 2018: $980 million profit 2017: $852 million profit 2016: $1.029 billion profit 2015: $560 million profit 2013: $5 million profit 2011:$249 million profit 2010: $112 million profit 2009: $117 million profit 2008: $969 million profit 2008 - 2022 Total annual net profit $4.7 billion

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Unions warn new Qantas CEO will have 'uphill' road ahead to rebuild
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Transport Workers Union has issued a statement about Vanessa Hudson's appointment to Qantas's top job, warning she will face an "uphill" road to rebuild the national carrier. TWU national secretary Michael Kaine says standards have been "shattered" over the 15 years Alan Joyce has been in the role, and says Ms Hudson has a "golden opportunity" to correct the airline's trajectory. “Today’s announcement is by no means a sign of relief to aviation workers, especially the 1,700 illegally sacked ground workers still suffering on the sidelines. But this is a golden opportunity for a reset at Qantas," he said. “Over a decade Alan Joyce has systematically splintered his workforce and driven down standards to the point where Qantas is a shadow of what it once was. "Joyce’s position became untenable because Qantas was treated as a corporate vessel for excessive executive bonuses and shareholder dividends. "Vanessa Hudson must be courageous enough to steer Qantas back to its core purpose: high-quality service for passengers and investment in the hard-working people who built the spirit of Australia." Mr Kaine says the union's door is open for Ms Hudson to meet with worker representatives, and comes as the new Qantas boss told a media conference she was looking forward to developing a "constructive relationship" with unions.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Watch: Vanessa Hudson on succeeding Alan Joyce as Qantas CEO
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Incoming Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson says she's "incredibly excited" to succeed Alan Joyce in the role, and she's looking forward to working with aviation unions to build constructive relationships.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: New CEO chosen from a 'very wide range' of potential candidates
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The final question of the media conference was directed to Qantas chair Richard Goyder about the potential candidates who were in the running to replace Alan Joyce. After a global search, Mr Goyder said there were close to 40 potential candidates, and "most of them were male". "The two outstanding candidates were the two internal female candidates, and the board went through the right process. "We spent time with Vanessa [Hudson] and Olivia [Wirth] and while I say it's never easy, the board firmly feels that [Vanessa] is the right person to take Qantas forward. "Not just because of her background and what she's achieved to date but we think she's got, in aviation terms, a lot of runway to build and grow her career, and in the process make sure that Qantas is bigger, better and stronger in the years ahead."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: New Qantas boss focused on improving customer experience
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: One major hurdle Ms Hudson will face as new CEO of Qantas will be improving customer relations and experiences, which have slipped in recent years in the wake of the COVID pandemic. She was asked about how she would restore the national carrier's reputation, to which she said improving customer experience will be at the forefront. "We are very up-front in terms of  recognising that the customer  experience was not where we wanted it to be, we have invested in an  enormous amount of money," she said. "This year again the performance is back where we were pre-COVID and our focus  going forward is going to continue to improve." "We have an enormous amount of initiatives that are in the  pipeline including investment in new lounges but most notably it we have a new pipeline of reviewing our  fleet which will deliver the next  step change in customer experience including Project Sunrise but it  will also deliver growth."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Leaving Qantas 'a bittersweet moment for me', Joyce says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Alan Joyce has used the first part of his speech to commend Qantas for making history in appointing Vanessa Hudson as his replacement. "I am  pleased that the 103 years of what this is history it has been at 12  CEOs," he said. "This is the first female CEO and that length of time and that is a credit to the merit and the  capability of the strong women that we have in the management team. "There's not many female CEOs in the worldwide aviation industry and as a credit to this country that gay man was appointed 15 years ago to be CEO of the company and now we have the first female accredited to the  board." Mr Joyce still has six months left in the role before he leaves in November, and says he still has plenty of work ahead of him. "I have a lot of things to do but this is certainly, going to be a bittersweet moment for me because  I'm passionate about this company, I am passionate about Qantas, it has been my life for so long but the  timing is right. "As Richard said, if it had not been for COVID I would have retired a few years ago. "I have agreed to stay if this length of  time to help the company get through that terrible crisis and make sure that it is strong coming out and I believe that we are really strong  now and settled well for the future."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Incoming CEO pays tribute to Joyce's time in the role
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's some of what incoming Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson has had to say about her history-making appointment: "I know that I would not be here if it was not for Alan, your leadership, the leadership team that I have  worked with over the last couple of years but also the broader people  that I have worked with across  Qantas, I know that they bring out the best in me and for them I would not be here today," she said. "It's such an honour to be stepping into this role in  November and I'm incredibly excited about not just the opportunity but about the future because there is so much to look forward to over the  coming years. "I am so passionate  about Qantas, I have worked for  Qantas for 28 years and the  excitement of the first day that I felt walking into Qantas, I feel  still today."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Qantas chair: Joyce has led us through turbulent times
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder has started the press conference thanking outgoing CEO Alan Joyce for his service. "There will be plenty of time to talk about Alan's achievement as the year and fold but I do want to recall the boards and my own  appreciation for everything Alan has done to date including leading the airline through a period of time  which was really existential in  terms of Qantas's outlook," Goyder said. "The  board and shareholders back in 2020 asked him to stay on through the  pandemic which he agreed to do."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Watch: Alan Joyce and new Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson to speak
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Outgoing Qantas CEO Alan Joyce is about to speak after the airline announced its chief financial officer, Vanessa Hudson would succeed him in the role. We'll also hear from the incoming CEO, Ms Hudson herself, who has made history as the first female CEO of Qantas in its 103-year history. You can watch the full press conference below, which is due to start shortly:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Woolworths records 8pc growth in sales as supply chains recover
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Woolworths Group has recorded an 8% growth in its sales in the third quarter compared to the same time last year, with growth across all of its businesses — including a near 8% increase in food sales. CEO Brad Banducci said supply chains are slowly recovering, but notes that customers are becoming increasingly wary about the impact that ongoing inflation is having on household budgets. "In general, customer spending is stable. However, v alue-conscious customers are becoming more thoughtful about their discretionary spend, trading into more affordable options such as our own brands and looking for additional ways to save in store or through our Digital, Rewards and eCommerce platforms," Mr Banducci said. The food sales arm of the business saw a 7.6% increase to $12.3 billion in the third quarter, with food retail sales growing by 7.4%.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Housing affordability worsens as property prices rise for second straight month
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: House prices have risen for the second month in a row, with analysts suggesting the market may have bottomed. Rents are also rising, which is putting extra pressure on the federal government to do something about the affordability crisis. It says it's not considering scrapping tax concessions, like negative gearing for investors, but will offer tax breaks to developers in next week's budget to build more rental properties. You can watch the full story from my colleague, business reporter Nassim Khadem, below 👇

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Incoming Qantas CEO says it's an 'honour' to lead national carrier
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Newly-appointed Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson says she is honoured to be appointed the company's 13th CEO in its 103-year history. Ms Hudson is the airline's first female CEO and has a long history with the company. She was part of the committee that shaped Qantas's strategy, helped it navigate the impacts of COVID, and led its fleet selection process. "It's an absolute honour to be asked to lead the national carrier. This is an exceptional  company full of incredibly talented people and it's very well positioned for the future," she said. "My focus will be  delivering for those we rely on and who rely on us — our customers, our employees, our shareholders and  the communities we serve." Qantas will announce its new CFO to replace Ms Hudson "in the months ahead". We'll hear more from outgoing CEO Alan Joyce and Ms Hudson later this morning.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'It's a logical time for me to step down', Joyce says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Outgoing Qantas boss Alan Joyce was asked to stay on as the airline's CEO as it recovered from the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, but Mr Joyce says now is the right time to step aside. "Now that we’re on the other side of that crisis it’s a logical time for me to step down," he said. "There’s still a  lot I want to deliver in the next six months and at the top of that list is ensuring a smooth handover to  Vanessa, who I’m sure will excel in the role." Qantas chair Richard Goyder paid tribute to Mr Joyce for his years at the helm of the national carrier. “Much of the credit for the bright future in front of Qantas goes to Alan," Mr Goyder said. "He’s faced more than his fair share  of challenges as CEO and he’s managed them exceptionally well – from the GFC, to record oil prices, to  intense competitive pressures and the COVID crisis. "The company was restructured to deal with a number of external shocks and Alan led it to a several record  profits. "Alan has done a superb job of leading a team that is absolutely committed to the national carrier’s long-term success and it’s from that team that his successor has been chosen."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: BREAKING: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce to step down in November, replaced by CFO Vanessa Hudson
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Qantas has confirmed this morning that current CEO Alan Joyce will retire in November this year and will be replaced by the group's chief financial officer Vanessa Hudson. Ms Hudson has worked across a number of positions with Qantas over the past 28 years, including chief customer officer and senior vice-president for the Americas and New Zealand. Qantas chairman Richard Goyder said the appointment came after a rigorous selection process for Mr Joyce's replacement. "Vanessa has a deep understanding of this business after almost three decades in a range of roles both onshore and offshore, across commercial, customer and finance," he said. Mr Joyce has been at the helm of Qantas for 15 years, and will step down in November after extending his tenure at the board's request to help the airline's COVID recovery.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Could the government see a budget surplus by the end of the year?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's certainly the optimistic forecasts by some, including independent economist Chris Richardson. He believes there's a chance of seeing a "wafer thin" surplus over the year to March, which would put treasurer Jim Chalmers in sight of the first budget surplus Australia has seen in 15 years. What's behind this potential surplus? Commodity prices, in particular booming iron ore and thermal coal prices. But that's not to say deficits will be a thing of the past — as senior business correspondent Peter Ryan explains in the clip below 👇

liveBlogUpdate.headline: House prices haven't just stabilised — they've turned the corner
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: CoreLogic data released yesterday show house prices have rebounded from their downturn, rising for a second consecutive month. Every capital city, with the exception of Darwin, saw a rise in real estate prices, led by Sydney. Regional areas also saw some minor gains. But against all logic and what previous experience has shown us, house prices appear to have not just stabilised but turned a corner. You can read more of this analysis by business editor Ian Verrender below 👇

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX set to slip as Reserve Bank rates decision looms
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good morning, it's Tuesday May 2 and you've found yourself on the ABC's markets and business blog — and what a day we have in front of us. Let's get the elephant in the room out of the way first: it's rates day. The RBA is meeting today to decide what to do with the cash rate, after leaving rates on hold at 3.6% in April. But we know that was a lineball call — in the meeting minutes published a couple of weeks later, the RBA board had considered another rise of 0.25 percentage points. So what could today's decision look like? Major banks and investors are widely predicting the RBA will leave the cash rate unchanged at 3.6%, with data last week showing inflation is slowly coming down. I'll bring you the latest on that decision when it happens at 2:30pm AEST, and all the reaction that follows. On the markets front, the Australian share market is looking to open lower this morning after ASX futures were down -0.1% to 7,336 points as of 7:30am. It follows a mixed performance on Wall Street overnight, with US financial markets largely dominated by the news that regulators had seized First Republic, before selling its assets to JPMorgan Chase to fight off another global banking crisis. First Republic is the third US bank to collapse in just two months, after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank folded earlier this year. All in all, there's a bit on — pour yourself a coffee and let's see where the day takes us.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Gareth, we are retirees and for some years our savings behave been earning tiny amounts of interest.  So I suppose one might say that it will be our turn for a little while.  If one looks at Australia’s interest rates over the last 40 years, interest rates have rarely been below 5% pa. - Miles. I have complete sympathy for you Miles. In the inflation-targeting era (since the early 1990s), interest rates have been in long-term decline - except for now. It's been increasingly great for asset owners. But people who rely on interest rates from their savings to supplement their income have not benefited.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Governments are getting off far too lightly re their contribution to this problem.  Even now various Budgets are promising relief for low/middle income and mortgaged households - fair enough.  But if this in not immediately countered by a tax hit to middle/high and home owning households the net impact on the economy (i.e. demand) is clearly going to be positive.  Completely at odds with what the RBA is trying to acheive...
 - Mike. There's a good point in here. Governments have got off too lightly for contributing to this inflation. The RBA has become a scapegoat of sorts. Your point about the budget is also interesting. There are credible forecasts at the moment that the Albanese Government could actually deliver an exceptionally-thin budget surplus next week. That's for a few reasons, but especially because commodity prices have been far higher than Treasury was forecasting, and because the exceptionally-high levels of immigration we're seeing out the moment are much higher than were forecast. And budget surpluses help to suck inflation out of the system. So on the surface, the budget settings look like they may be supporting the RBA's attempt to dampen inflation. But that's only on the surface. The budget will probably show that there will be a heap of structural problems down the line that will be hard to address.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Given that this period of rapid inflation is reported to have been affected by high corporate profits rather than wages, why is the RBA so focused on slowing/preventing wage growth? To someone who doesn't know a lot about economics, it almost feels like they're taking the easy way out trying to keep the big companies happy. - Bec. The RBA can't do much about supply. It can only influence demand (in the short and medium term) by moving interest rates up and down. That's why the RBA is always keeping an eye on wages because wages feed into demand-driven inflation. This is just the system past policymakers built. In the inflation-targeting era, it's been the RBA's job to manage inflation - and the economic cycle - by moving interest rates around to influence demand .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is it a cop-out?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hi just wondering if there is any historical data that's shows how high previous inflation rates were when they actually triggered a recession or a recessionary curve. As a baby boomer who lived through interest rates of 12% and higher 30 years ago, current inflation seems not high at all - Bill. A significant difference with today's environment, compared to past eras, is the level of debt in the economy. When my folks bought their first home in the early 1970s it cost them $35,000. That was 3x their annual income. Today, properties are typically worth upwards of 7x annual income, and well above 10x to 12x in some of our capital cities. And because the cash rate was 0.1% for a time, the size of the recent mortgages banks were willing to extend to people were huge. So, relatively small increases in interest rates are much more impactful today. Now, this might be a slightly left-field way of answering your question quickly, but I recently made a graph of the time when Australia's economic authorities experimented with targeting the money supply to control inflation (at the peak of Milton Friedman's monetarism craze in the late 1970s and early 1980s). It was when Malcolm Fraser was prime minister and John Howard was Treasurer (for most of the time). There were three recessions in that period, including the recession in the early 1980s which was especially bad. It shows how high inflation was in that era. Note inflation fell after each recession. Although, inflation shot up again in 1985, after the Hawke Government floated the dollar in 1983 and deregulated the financial sector.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Alan Oster, NAB's chief economist, says he's finding it difficult to understand the RBA board's behaviour lately. He spoke to my colleague David Chau earlier, and he had this to say about today's rate hike and the accompanying statement from governor Phil Lowe. Q: "Recent property market data for Canberra showed house prices are on their way up again. Is the wealth effect something the RBA may be concerned about? Especially if house prices continue their recovery? People might feel they are better off economically and might spend more, which might make it harder for the Reserve Bank to bring inflation down? Alan Oster: "That is possible. But let's face it. It is mainly a Sydney thing. Up over 1% in Sydney and across Australia, 0.5%. "Yes, there is a wealth effect associated, but also a very direct interest-rate effect. It is much bigger than the wealth effect. The nice news is these are probably bottoming out. But the fact that the economy is still going to slow I think is an issue. "Once again the Reserve Bank made it very difficult for us all to understand what the hell they are talking about, to be brutally honest," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Puzzled. Befuddled. Bemused.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: CoreLogic's research director, Tim Lawless thinks today's rate hike will be the last of this cycle. He says today's interest rate decision was always going to be a "line ball", but "the 25 basis point lift is likely to be the last in what has been the most rapid rate hiking cycle on record". "Although inflation has been trending lower since peaking in the December quarter 2022, today’s rate hike reflects the RBA’s uncertainty about how ‘sticky’ inflation might be amid persistently tight labour markets and new evidence that housing prices have moved through their low point," Mr Lawless said. "Although the RBA didn’t touch on the recent more positive housing trend, the statement following the meeting highlighted the rapid drop in housing prices since rate hikes commenced could be a factor in slowing household spending (alongside high interest rates and high cost of living pressures). "Time will tell whether the latest rate hike is enough to send the recent positive trend in home values into reverse, however our anticipation is the market will continue to level out on the expectation that interest rates have peaked and the imbalance between housing demand and supply will persist for some time yet."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rate hike 'likely to be the last', CoreLogic says

children.content: CoreLogic's research director, Tim Lawless thinks today's rate hike will be the last of this cycle.
He says today's interest rate decision was always going to be a "line ball", but "the 25 basis point lift is likely to be the last in what has been the most rapid rate hiking cycle on record".

"Although inflation has been trending lower since peaking in the December quarter 2022, today’s rate hike reflects the RBA’s uncertainty about how ‘sticky’ inflation might be amid persistently tight labour markets and new evidence that housing prices have moved through their low point," Mr Lawless said.

"Although the RBA didn’t touch on the recent more positive housing trend, the statement following the meeting highlighted the rapid drop in housing prices since rate hikes commenced could be a factor in slowing household spending (alongside high interest rates and high cost of living pressures).

"Time will tell whether the latest rate hike is enough to send the recent positive trend in home values into reverse, however our anticipation is the market will continue to level out on the expectation that interest rates have peaked and the imbalance between housing demand and supply will persist for some time yet."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Given the RBA’s comment that they expect inflation to reduce to 3% by mid-2025 (upper bound of the target range) are we likely to see ongoing rate hikes until then? - Vickie. Economists say it would be reasonable to expect rates to rise a little more this year, but I haven't seen anyone suggest that rates will keep rising until mid-2025. There are still hundreds of thousands of households with fixed-rate mortgages that have yet to roll onto variable loans. When they do, they'll be getting a big interest rate shock. The RBA's aware of that. It knows there's a lag between rate hikes and their impact on economic activity, and it's expecting inflation to slowly fall over the next 24 months as the rate rises that have already occurred work their way through the system.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rates rises until...

children.content: Given the RBA’s comment that they expect inflation to reduce to 3% by mid-2025 (upper bound of the target range) are we likely to see ongoing rate hikes until then?

There are still hundreds of thousands of households with fixed-rate mortgages that have yet to roll onto variable loans. When they do, they'll be getting a big interest rate shock.

The RBA's aware of that. It knows there's a lag between rate hikes and their impact on economic activity, and it's expecting inflation to slowly fall over the next 24 months as the rate rises that have already occurred work their way through the system.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Am I understanding this correctly? Is the policy really to keep wage growth down? - Sean. Central banks say they can only control demand. They have no control over supply. So when they move interest rates up and down, they're trying to manipulate demand. Wages are one of the key drivers of demand, and employment (and unemployment) drives wages. The RBA knows this inflationary episode didn't start with exceptionally-strong wages growth. But it's very concerned that workers will demand (and start winning) wage growth to match this high inflation because that could spark a "wage-price spiral," which would, in turn, make it even harder for the RBA to get this inflation back down and under control. So, the RBA doesn't want wages to grow too quickly. It wants them to stay relatively subdued and for these high prices to eventually wash out of the system, so everything can go back to normal.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The RBA's focus on demand and wages

children.content: Am I understanding this correctly? Is the policy really to keep wage growth down?
- Sean
Central banks say they can only control demand. They have no control over supply.
So when they move interest rates up and down, they're trying to manipulate demand. Wages are one of the key drivers of demand, and employment (and unemployment) drives wages.

The RBA knows this inflationary episode didn't start with exceptionally-strong wages growth. But it's very concerned that workers will demand (and start winning) wage growth to match this high inflation because that could spark a "wage-price spiral," which would, in turn, make it even harder for the RBA to get this inflation back down and under control.
So, the RBA doesn't want wages to grow too quickly. It wants them to stay relatively subdued and for these high prices to eventually wash out of the system, so everything can go back to normal.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here are some comments from Callam Pickering, an economist at global job site Indeed. Mr Pickering is a former RBA economist so he has insight into how RBA officials would be thinking about things. He's just put out this note on the rate decision, which I think is worth quoting in full: "The flow of recent economic data provides a compelling case for further rate hikes,” he said. "While it was also possible to mount a convincing argument for no change, the RBA clearly felt that economic conditions remained too strong to facilitate a sustainable return to its 2-3% inflation target within a reasonable time-frame. "The RBA anticipates that further rate hikes may well be needed to defeat the current inflation outbreak. However, given that rate hikes hit the Australian economy with a considerable lag, the RBA is also mindful that the economy hasn’t yet felt the full impact of the first rate hikes let alone the ones that followed. That points towards a pretty measured and cautious approach over the next three to six months. "The key challenge for the RBA is balancing the risks of high inflation against the likelihood that excess tightening plunges the economy into a recession or severe downturn which harms Australian workers and businesses unnecessarily. There is plenty of anecdotal evidence of households doing it rough but so far that hasn’t translated into any meaningful moderation in household or business spending. "While there were signs of inflation moderating in the monthly figures, sources of domestically-driven inflation remained too strong. Prices of non-tradable goods - a useful proxy for inflation driven by domestic factors - have increased at an annualised pace of 8.1% over the past six months. It won’t be possible for inflation to sustainably return to its 2-3% target unless that number gets down to the high 3% or low 4% range. "Unfortunately, achieving that requires you to squash domestic demand for goods and services. That normally means higher unemployment, reduced household spending and business investment." " That said, we anticipate that the Australian economy will slow considerably over the second half of the year. This is centered on the belief that household conditions will deteriorate due to the combination of much higher mortgage repayments, softish asset prices and the unprecedented decline in inflation-adjusted wages. This is a recipe for an economic slowdown if ever I’ve seen one. "While the May increase will come as an unwelcome surprise to many, we don’t anticipate that rates will continue to rise for long. "We are very close to rates reaching the cycle peak and that will likely become clear over the next three to six months.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More rate hikes, and a recipe for an economic slowdown

children.content: Here are some comments from Callam Pickering, an economist at global job site Indeed.
Mr Pickering is a former RBA economist so he has insight into how RBA officials would be thinking about things.
He's just put out this note on the rate decision, which I think is worth quoting in full:
"The flow of recent economic data provides a compelling case for further rate hikes,” he said.

"While it was also possible to mount a convincing argument for no change, the RBA clearly felt that economic conditions remained too strong to facilitate a sustainable return to its 2-3% inflation target within a reasonable time-frame.

"The RBA anticipates that further rate hikes may well be needed to defeat the current inflation outbreak. However, given that rate hikes hit the Australian economy with a considerable lag, the RBA is also mindful that the economy hasn’t yet felt the full impact of the first rate hikes let alone the ones that followed. That points towards a pretty measured and cautious approach over the next three to six months.

"The key challenge for the RBA is balancing the risks of high inflation against the likelihood that excess tightening plunges the economy into a recession or severe downturn which harms Australian workers and businesses unnecessarily. There is plenty of anecdotal evidence of households doing it rough but so far that hasn’t translated into any meaningful moderation in household or business spending.

"While there were signs of inflation moderating in the monthly figures, sources of domestically-driven inflation remained too strong. Prices of non-tradable goods - a useful proxy for inflation driven by domestic factors - have increased at an annualised pace of 8.1% over the past six months. It won’t be possible for inflation to sustainably return to its 2-3% target unless that number gets down to the high 3% or low 4% range.
"Unfortunately, achieving that requires you to squash domestic demand for goods and services. That normally means higher unemployment, reduced household spending and business investment."
That said, we anticipate that the Australian economy will slow considerably over the second half of the year.

This is centered on the belief that household conditions will deteriorate due to the combination of much higher mortgage repayments, softish asset prices and the unprecedented decline in inflation-adjusted wages.
This is a recipe for an economic slowdown if ever I’ve seen one.
"While the May increase will come as an unwelcome surprise to many, we don’t anticipate that rates will continue to rise for long.
"We are very close to rates reaching the cycle peak and that will likely become clear over the next three to six months.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Dr Dwyfor Evans, the Head of APAC Macro Strategy at State Street Global Markets, says it's interesting what Phil Lowe has focused on in his statement following the monetary policy decision. "Inflation remains high relative to target, but the softer core inflation released last week gave the Bank some breathing space, particularly on concerns around mortgage rates, but the focus in this instance is high services prices and rising labour costs ," Mr Evans said. That's a reference to these lines in Dr Lowe's statement. " Services price inflation is still very high and broadly based and the experience overseas points to upside risks. " Unit labour costs are also rising briskly, with productivity growth remaining subdued. " Wages growth has picked up in response to the tight labour market and high inflation. At the aggregate level, wages growth is still consistent with the inflation target, provided that productivity growth picks up. The Board remains alert to the risk that expectations of ongoing high inflation contribute to larger increases in both prices and wages, especially given the limited spare capacity in the economy and the historically low rate of unemployment. Accordingly, it will continue to pay close attention to both the evolution of labour costs and the price-setting behaviour of firms. " So Dr Evans thinks that, even though core inflation has weakened enough recently to give the RBA some breathing space, the RBA is concerned enough about wages growth picking up that it wants to crimp some more demand. What's your experience with wages right now?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The RBA doesn't want wages growing too quickly

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's the question plenty of borrowers and economists have right now, and there are some clues in the statement issued by RBA governor Philip Lowe. Here's an excerpt from that statement: "Inflation in Australia has passed its peak, but at 7 per cent is still too high and it will be some time yet before it is back in the target range," the statement said. "Given the importance of returning inflation to target within a reasonable timeframe, the Board judged that a further increase in interest rates was warranted today. "The Board held interest rates steady last month to provide additional time to assess the state of the economy and the outlook. "While the recent data showed a welcome decline in inflation, the central forecast remains that it takes a couple of years before inflation returns to the top of the target range; inflation is expected to be 4.5% in 2023 and 3% in mid-2025."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Inflation has 'passed its peak' but rate rise still needed, RBA says

cent is still too high and it will be some time yet before it is back in the target range," the statement said.
"Given the importance of returning inflation to target within a reasonable timeframe, the Board judged that a further increase in interest rates was warranted today.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The RBA has increased the cash rate by 0.25 percentage points to 3.85%, after a one-off pause last month. It's the 11th increase in the space of a year. The move caught most traders by surprise, with the market only pricing in a 13 per cent chance of rates rising ahead of the RBA's 2:30pm AEST announcement. The majority of the major bank economists were also tipping the Reserve Bank to remain on hold this month, with two forecasting that it had reached the peak of its rate hike cycle at 3.6 per cent. The latest rate increase will add around $78 a month onto repayments for a half a million dollar home loan, if passed on in full by the banks. A customer owing $500,000 will now have seen their repayments rise by around $1,058 a month since the RBA started hiking rates in May last year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA lifts cash rate by 0.25 percentage points to 3.85%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ahead of this afternoon's cash rate decision by the Reserve Bank board, Australia's big four banks have been predicting what the decision might be based on recent economic data. Three out of four think they will hold — while one bank thinks another 0.25 percentage point hike is on the way today. ANZ : hold at 3.6% Westpac : hold at 3.6% NAB : hold at 3.6% CBA : increase to 3.85% In fact, not only does Westpac think another pause is likely — they think interest rates have peaked at 3.6%. Markets are also expecting the RBA to leave rates on hold.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Qantas news has really dominated much of the business news today, but there's still another major event coming up — interest rates. You're forgiven if it's slipped your mind, but in around an hour's time we'll hear what the RBA board has decided to do with the cash rate this month. It's widely tipped that rates will remain on hold at 3.6%, but at last month's meeting the board refused to rule out a future interest rate rise. We'll also get a bit more of an insight than normal into the bank's decision later on today too. Not only will the written decision for rates be published online at 2:30pm AEST, but governor Philip Lowe will be giving a speech at the RBA board dinner in Perth tonight. That's happening at 9:20pm AEST (which works out to be a more respectable 7:20pm in the west). The news just doesn't stop today — but stick with us and we'll bring you the latest as it unfolds.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Vanessa Hudson has committed to improving the customer experience during her time as Qantas's chief executive, and judging by customers who reporter Harriet Tatham has spoken to today, they remain divided on the service provided by the national carrier. She spoke to passengers at Sydney's domestic Qantas terminal earlier today, who have mixed views on how the airline treats its customers. "I don't think they've don't everything perfect in the last couple of years but it's a tough gig," said Tracey Cooper, who arrived from Brisbane on a Qantas flight. Ron, who didn't provide his surname and flew in from Melbourne, says he thinks a number of Qantas customers are disappointed by the service. "Qantas was always a brand you loved and respected," he said. "I think COVID was rough on a lot of airlines and financially airlines took a hit and I think the way that Qantas responded to that has meant that their level of services dropped. "Customers who were very loyal to Qantas are questioning whether that loyalty was misplaced. "So I think they've got a way to go to win back their customers … and it's a good time for new management to come in and shake things up." But fellow passenger Nuzhat Abonty, who also arrived on the Melbourne flight, spoke very highly of the brand. "The service is amazing — especially the staff, the comfortable seats."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas customers remain divided on the airline's service

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hi there, Sue Lannin jumping in for a guest post. I've been crunching Qantas' bottom line, and it has made huge losses during the 15 years of outgoing chief executive Alan Joyce's tenure. Aviation is a tough industry, with wars, pandemics, natural disasters, economic slowdowns, and financial crises the main factors that drive away passengers. Over the past 15 years, Qantas has been hit by COVID-19, which shut down the global travel industry, high fuel costs, fleet writedowns, and the global financial crisis, when toxic investments in the US almost brought down the world's financial system. So let's have a look at the financials while Mr Joyce was at the helm. Qantas net profit verses losses breakdown From 2008 to 2022, Qantas lost $2.9 billion, which wiped out the profits it made during the period. The rebound from COVID-19 has seen the airline return to profit for 2023, making a record $1 billion for the half year. Annual net losses 2022: $860 million loss 2021: $1.7 billion loss 2020: $1.9 billion loss 2014: $2.83 billion loss 2012: $$245 million loss 2008 - 2022 Total annual net loss: $7.6 billion Annual net profits 2019: $891 million profit 2018: $980 million profit 2017: $852 million profit 2016: $1.029 billion profit 2015: $560 million profit 2013: $5 million profit 2011:$249 million profit 2010: $112 million profit 2009: $117 million profit 2008: $969 million profit 2008 - 2022 Total annual net profit $4.7 billion

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Transport Workers Union has issued a statement about Vanessa Hudson's appointment to Qantas's top job, warning she will face an "uphill" road to rebuild the national carrier. TWU national secretary Michael Kaine says standards have been "shattered" over the 15 years Alan Joyce has been in the role, and says Ms Hudson has a "golden opportunity" to correct the airline's trajectory. “Today’s announcement is by no means a sign of relief to aviation workers, especially the 1,700 illegally sacked ground workers still suffering on the sidelines. But this is a golden opportunity for a reset at Qantas," he said. “Over a decade Alan Joyce has systematically splintered his workforce and driven down standards to the point where Qantas is a shadow of what it once was. "Joyce’s position became untenable because Qantas was treated as a corporate vessel for excessive executive bonuses and shareholder dividends. "Vanessa Hudson must be courageous enough to steer Qantas back to its core purpose: high-quality service for passengers and investment in the hard-working people who built the spirit of Australia." Mr Kaine says the union's door is open for Ms Hudson to meet with worker representatives, and comes as the new Qantas boss told a media conference she was looking forward to developing a "constructive relationship" with unions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unions warn new Qantas CEO will have 'uphill' road ahead to rebuild

children.content: The Transport Workers Union has issued a statement about Vanessa Hudson's appointment to Qantas's top job, warning she will face an "uphill" road to rebuild the national carrier.

TWU national secretary Michael Kaine says standards have been "shattered" over the 15 years Alan Joyce has been in the role, and says Ms Hudson has a "golden opportunity" to correct the airline's trajectory.

“Today’s announcement is by no means a sign of relief to aviation workers, especially the 1,700 illegally sacked ground workers still suffering on the sidelines. But this is a golden opportunity for a reset at Qantas," he said.
“Over a decade Alan Joyce has systematically splintered his workforce and driven down standards to the point where Qantas is a shadow of what it once was.
"Joyce’s position became untenable because Qantas was treated as a corporate vessel for excessive executive bonuses and shareholder dividends.
"Vanessa Hudson must be courageous enough to steer Qantas back to its core purpose: high-quality service for passengers and investment in the hard-working people who built the spirit of Australia."

Mr Kaine says the union's door is open for Ms Hudson to meet with worker representatives, and comes as the new Qantas boss told a media conference she was looking forward to developing a "constructive relationship" with unions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The final question of the media conference was directed to Qantas chair Richard Goyder about the potential candidates who were in the running to replace Alan Joyce. After a global search, Mr Goyder said there were close to 40 potential candidates, and "most of them were male". "The two outstanding candidates were the two internal female candidates, and the board went through the right process. "We spent time with Vanessa [Hudson] and Olivia [Wirth] and while I say it's never easy, the board firmly feels that [Vanessa] is the right person to take Qantas forward. "Not just because of her background and what she's achieved to date but we think she's got, in aviation terms, a lot of runway to build and grow her career, and in the process make sure that Qantas is bigger, better and stronger in the years ahead."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New CEO chosen from a 'very wide range' of potential candidates

children.content: The final question of the media conference was directed to Qantas chair Richard Goyder about the potential candidates who were in the running to replace Alan Joyce.
After a global search, Mr Goyder said there were close to 40 potential candidates, and "most of them were male".
"The two outstanding candidates were the two internal female candidates, and the board went through the right process.
"We spent time with Vanessa [Hudson] and Olivia [Wirth] and while I say it's never easy, the board firmly feels that [Vanessa] is the right person to take Qantas forward.

"Not just because of her background and what she's achieved to date but we think she's got, in aviation terms, a lot of runway to build and grow her career, and in the process make sure that Qantas is bigger, better and stronger in the years ahead."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One major hurdle Ms Hudson will face as new CEO of Qantas will be improving customer relations and experiences, which have slipped in recent years in the wake of the COVID pandemic. She was asked about how she would restore the national carrier's reputation, to which she said improving customer experience will be at the forefront. "We are very up-front in terms of  recognising that the customer  experience was not where we wanted it to be, we have invested in an  enormous amount of money," she said. "This year again the performance is back where we were pre-COVID and our focus  going forward is going to continue to improve." "We have an enormous amount of initiatives that are in the  pipeline including investment in new lounges but most notably it we have a new pipeline of reviewing our  fleet which will deliver the next  step change in customer experience including Project Sunrise but it  will also deliver growth."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Alan Joyce has used the first part of his speech to commend Qantas for making history in appointing Vanessa Hudson as his replacement. "I am  pleased that the 103 years of what this is history it has been at 12  CEOs," he said. "This is the first female CEO and that length of time and that is a credit to the merit and the  capability of the strong women that we have in the management team. "There's not many female CEOs in the worldwide aviation industry and as a credit to this country that gay man was appointed 15 years ago to be CEO of the company and now we have the first female accredited to the  board." Mr Joyce still has six months left in the role before he leaves in November, and says he still has plenty of work ahead of him. "I have a lot of things to do but this is certainly, going to be a bittersweet moment for me because  I'm passionate about this company, I am passionate about Qantas, it has been my life for so long but the  timing is right. "As Richard said, if it had not been for COVID I would have retired a few years ago. "I have agreed to stay if this length of  time to help the company get through that terrible crisis and make sure that it is strong coming out and I believe that we are really strong  now and settled well for the future."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's some of what incoming Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson has had to say about her history-making appointment: "I know that I would not be here if it was not for Alan, your leadership, the leadership team that I have  worked with over the last couple of years but also the broader people  that I have worked with across  Qantas, I know that they bring out the best in me and for them I would not be here today," she said. "It's such an honour to be stepping into this role in  November and I'm incredibly excited about not just the opportunity but about the future because there is so much to look forward to over the  coming years. "I am so passionate  about Qantas, I have worked for  Qantas for 28 years and the  excitement of the first day that I felt walking into Qantas, I feel  still today."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Woolworths Group has recorded an 8% growth in its sales in the third quarter compared to the same time last year, with growth across all of its businesses — including a near 8% increase in food sales. CEO Brad Banducci said supply chains are slowly recovering, but notes that customers are becoming increasingly wary about the impact that ongoing inflation is having on household budgets. "In general, customer spending is stable. However, v alue-conscious customers are becoming more thoughtful about their discretionary spend, trading into more affordable options such as our own brands and looking for additional ways to save in store or through our Digital, Rewards and eCommerce platforms," Mr Banducci said. The food sales arm of the business saw a 7.6% increase to $12.3 billion in the third quarter, with food retail sales growing by 7.4%.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Newly-appointed Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson says she is honoured to be appointed the company's 13th CEO in its 103-year history. Ms Hudson is the airline's first female CEO and has a long history with the company. She was part of the committee that shaped Qantas's strategy, helped it navigate the impacts of COVID, and led its fleet selection process. "It's an absolute honour to be asked to lead the national carrier. This is an exceptional  company full of incredibly talented people and it's very well positioned for the future," she said. "My focus will be  delivering for those we rely on and who rely on us — our customers, our employees, our shareholders and  the communities we serve." Qantas will announce its new CFO to replace Ms Hudson "in the months ahead". We'll hear more from outgoing CEO Alan Joyce and Ms Hudson later this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Incoming Qantas CEO says it's an 'honour' to lead national carrier

children.content: Newly-appointed Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson says she is honoured to be appointed the company's 13th CEO in its 103-year history.
Ms Hudson is the airline's first female CEO and has a long history with the company.
She was part of the committee that shaped Qantas's strategy, helped it navigate the impacts of COVID, and led its fleet selection process.
"It's an absolute honour to be asked to lead the national carrier. This is an exceptional  company full of incredibly talented people and it's very well positioned for the future," she said.
"My focus will be  delivering for those we rely on and who rely on us — our customers, our employees, our shareholders and  the communities we serve."
Qantas will announce its new CFO to replace Ms Hudson "in the months ahead".
We'll hear more from outgoing CEO Alan Joyce and Ms Hudson later this morning.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Outgoing Qantas boss Alan Joyce was asked to stay on as the airline's CEO as it recovered from the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, but Mr Joyce says now is the right time to step aside. "Now that we’re on the other side of that crisis it’s a logical time for me to step down," he said. "There’s still a  lot I want to deliver in the next six months and at the top of that list is ensuring a smooth handover to  Vanessa, who I’m sure will excel in the role." Qantas chair Richard Goyder paid tribute to Mr Joyce for his years at the helm of the national carrier. “Much of the credit for the bright future in front of Qantas goes to Alan," Mr Goyder said. "He’s faced more than his fair share  of challenges as CEO and he’s managed them exceptionally well – from the GFC, to record oil prices, to  intense competitive pressures and the COVID crisis. "The company was restructured to deal with a number of external shocks and Alan led it to a several record  profits. "Alan has done a superb job of leading a team that is absolutely committed to the national carrier’s long-term success and it’s from that team that his successor has been chosen."
