liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has confirmed this morning that current CEO Alan Joyce will retire in November this year and will be replaced by the group's chief financial officer Vanessa Hudson. Ms Hudson has worked across a number of positions with Qantas over the past 28 years, including chief customer officer and senior vice-president for the Americas and New Zealand. Qantas chairman Richard Goyder said the appointment came after a rigorous selection process for Mr Joyce's replacement. "Vanessa has a deep understanding of this business after almost three decades in a range of roles both onshore and offshore, across commercial, customer and finance," he said. Mr Joyce has been at the helm of Qantas for 15 years, and will step down in November after extending his tenure at the board's request to help the airline's COVID recovery.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, it's Tuesday May 2 and you've found yourself on the ABC's markets and business blog — and what a day we have in front of us. Let's get the elephant in the room out of the way first: it's rates day. The RBA is meeting today to decide what to do with the cash rate, after leaving rates on hold at 3.6% in April. But we know that was a lineball call — in the meeting minutes published a couple of weeks later, the RBA board had considered another rise of 0.25 percentage points. So what could today's decision look like? Major banks and investors are widely predicting the RBA will leave the cash rate unchanged at 3.6%, with data last week showing inflation is slowly coming down. I'll bring you the latest on that decision when it happens at 2:30pm AEST, and all the reaction that follows. On the markets front, the Australian share market is looking to open lower this morning after ASX futures were down -0.1% to 7,336 points as of 7:30am. It follows a mixed performance on Wall Street overnight, with US financial markets largely dominated by the news that regulators had seized First Republic, before selling its assets to JPMorgan Chase to fight off another global banking crisis. First Republic is the third US bank to collapse in just two months, after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank folded earlier this year. All in all, there's a bit on — pour yourself a coffee and let's see where the day takes us.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to slip as Reserve Bank rates decision looms

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has plummeted to finish at its lowest level in more than three weeks, after the RBA announced a surprise 11th rate hike in the past 12 months. The ASX200 finished down 67.2 points, or 0.92% at 7,267. All sectors finished in the red, with the real estate sector shedding the most, down -2.1%. The biggest gains of the day went to: Pinnacle Investment +6.1% Cleanaway Waste Management +5.8% Lake Resources +5.65 Telix Pharmaceuticals +3.1% Graincorp +2.2% The bottom five worst performers for the day were: Computershare -4.8% Mirvac -4.2% Imugene -3.9% De Grey Mining -3.75 Bellevue Gold -3.6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX plummets to three-week low after RBA hikes rates

children.content: The Australian share market has plummeted to finish at its lowest level in more than three weeks, after the RBA announced a surprise 11th rate hike in the past 12 months.
The ASX200 finished down 67.2 points, or 0.92% at 7,267.
All sectors finished in the red, with the real estate sector shedding the most, down -2.1%.
The biggest gains of the day went to:
Pinnacle Investment +6.1%
Cleanaway Waste Management +5.8%
Lake Resources +5.65
Telix Pharmaceuticals +3.1%
Graincorp +2.2%
The bottom five worst performers for the day were:
Computershare -4.8%
Mirvac -4.2%
Imugene -3.9%
De Grey Mining -3.75
Bellevue Gold -3.6%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Our investigations team would like your help. Today’s hike will increase the pressure on borrowers who took out large loans while rates were at historic lows. ABC Investigations has launched a crowdsourced investigation into mortgage lending in Australia. They’re investigating how we got into this situation, who is to blame and what needs to change – and they need your help. If you have a mortgage, or if you work in lending, regulation or financial support services, they want to hear from you. Go to abc.net.au/lending to share your story.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Help the ABC investigate mortgage lending

children.content: Our investigations team would like your help.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's the question plenty of borrowers and economists have right now, and there are some clues in the statement issued by RBA governor Philip Lowe. Here's an excerpt from that statement: "Inflation in Australia has passed its peak, but at 7 per cent is still too high and it will be some time yet before it is back in the target range," the statement said. "Given the importance of returning inflation to target within a reasonable timeframe, the Board judged that a further increase in interest rates was warranted today. "The Board held interest rates steady last month to provide additional time to assess the state of the economy and the outlook. "While the recent data showed a welcome decline in inflation, the central forecast remains that it takes a couple of years before inflation returns to the top of the target range; inflation is expected to be 4.5% in 2023 and 3% in mid-2025."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Inflation has 'passed its peak' but rate rise still needed, RBA says

children.content: It's the question plenty of borrowers and economists have right now, and there are some clues in the statement issued by RBA governor Philip Lowe.
Here's an excerpt from that statement:
"Inflation in Australia has passed its peak, but at 7
per
cent is still too high and it will be some time yet before it is back in the target range," the statement said.
"Given the importance of returning inflation to target within a reasonable timeframe, the Board judged that a further increase in interest rates was warranted today.
"The Board held interest rates steady last month to provide additional time to assess the state of the economy and the outlook.

"While the recent data showed a welcome decline in inflation, the central forecast remains that it takes a couple of years before inflation returns to the top of the target range; inflation is expected to be 4.5% in 2023 and 3% in mid-2025."
